responses.rationale: Factual reporting of case locations without explicit framing cues.
Factual description of transmission and potential outcome ('can prove deadly') without amplification.
Factual reporting of expected price increase and reasons. 'Surge' describes background condition (prices).
'concerning' is explicit language indicating worry/alarm.
Factual report about scientists identifying the virus type.
Factual statement about retirement.
Asks a question about feelings regarding factual developments ('lengthening list') described neutrally.
Asks questions about feelings and potential future, presented neutrally.
Quote stating plausibility of discussions.
Neutral reporting of asking experts for their assessment and level of concern.
'raised the specter' is explicit language suggesting fear or worry.
Factual description of virus movement.
'worries me' is explicit language indicating concern/alarm.
Factual statement about a past 'pandemic threat', using standard terminology.
Factual description of an outbreak and outcomes ('sickening and killing').
'gives flu researchers pause' is explicit language suggesting concern.
Rhetorical question implying potential risk, but not explicit framing.
Statement about difficulty assessing significance, presented factually.
Factual statement about past capacity to infect mammals.
Factual report of animal deaths.
Factual report of past infections detected.
Factual report of dead and sick birds.
Factual description of a person's activity.
Factual description of people's location/activity.
Factual description of a person's history.
Factual description of a case as 'rare severe case' using factual descriptors.
Describes a school of thought about reasons for decline in cases.
Factual statement about origin.
Factual statement about cause of human infections.
Describes the virus version and gene acquisition neutrally.
'worries primarily' is explicit language indicating concern/alarm.
'There will be a new pandemic for sure' is a strong, certain prediction of a negative event.
Reports expert opinion using standard terminology ('spillover threats') without amplification.
'major problem' is an explicit evaluative phrase indicating severity.
Factual statement about joining CDC and involvement.
Lists factual negative outcomes ('severe lower respiratory tract infection', 'fatal outcomes') using factual descriptors.
Factual statement about virus prevalence.
'worries about' is explicit language indicating concern/alarm.
Expresses difficulty regarding public response to a potential future event, not framing the threat itself.
Lists organizations involved in lobbying.
Reports a supplier 'suffered multiple outbreaks' using factual description of scale.
'hit particularly hard' is explicit language indicating severe negative impact.
'fears' is explicit language indicating concern/alarm.
Describes how avian flu spreads factually.
Describes how avian flu spreads factually.
'likely to worsen' frames the situation negatively.
Factual reporting of situation change and expert suspicion using standard terms.
Describes who doses are intended for.
'risk... is considered to be low' is explicit reassuring language.
Factual report of a case detection.
States people are at 'higher risk' which is a factual comparison of risk levels.
Factual reporting of a new outbreak and virus identification. 'Highly pathogenic' is technical.
Defines HPAI and how it spreads factually. 'Highly pathogenic' is technical.
States the virus can 'sometimes jump into animals' using common descriptive language.
States where latest cases were factually.
'It is rare' is explicit reassuring language.
Describes who was infected and their contact factually.
Asks a question.
Reports first outbreak and spread factually. 'Highly pathogenic' is technical.
Describes how the disease is carried and transmitted factually.
Reports outbreaks and spread using factual descriptors ('severe', 'spreading quickly').
Factual statement about attracting attention due to transmission potential.
Reports an outbreak location and confirmation factually.
Identifies the serotype factually.
Describes how bird flu circulates and spreads factually.
Reports an action followed similar moves factually.
'in rare cases' is explicit reassuring language.
Factual report of the 'first death' globally. 'Highly pathogenic' is technical.
Reports strain identification at a location factually.
Reports WHO advising of the 'first global death' factually.
Reports discovery of a strain factually. 'Highly pathogenic' is technical.
States the industry has been dealing with an outbreak factually.
States a farm is the 'first' where flu was found this year factually.
Reports cases and how the virus spreads 'easily' which is a factual description of efficiency.
'Infections in humans are rare' is explicit reassuring language.
'only suffered conjunctivitis' minimizes the severity of the outcome.
Describes where the person works and the outbreak location factually.
'mild symptoms' minimizes the severity.
Reports when cows began testing positive factually.
'risk to the general public remains low' is explicit reassuring language.
Reports a hypothesis about viral fragments factually.
Reports a related human case linked to an outbreak factually.
Reports results were released/published factually.
States literature is 'scant but encouraging', framing the literature, not the threat.
Reports CDC launching a dashboard factually.
Reports agreement that the field 'has to learn' factually.
Reports data is what authorities are 'hungry for', framing the desire for data, not the threat.
Describes virus characteristics ('notorious') and potential risks factually.
Reports patient hospitalization and underlying conditions factually.
'risk to the general public from avian flu remains low' is explicit reassuring language.
Factual comparison of virus characteristics.
Reports confirmation by a department factually.
Reports HPAI 'has just crossed a new frontier', a factual development described metaphorically but not alarmingly.
'raises concerns' is explicit language indicating worry/alarm.
Describes outbreak start and observing a 'significant rise' in deaths factually.
Quote stating a correlation between adaptation and importance for humans neutrally.
'worrying ability' is explicit language indicating concern/alarm.
Reports causing 'significant mortality' factually.
Reports reaching Americas with cases reported factually.
Reports detection and when mammals began showing symptoms factually.
Reports authors stressed 'importance of continued research' neutrally.
Quote stating transmission mechanism factually.
Describes exposure level ('most intense') and lack of resources factually.
Reports symptoms experienced factually.
Reports a belief about undercounting factually.
Quote criticizing a method ('very passive') factually.
Reports CDC belief that risk is 'low', which is reassuring language.
Quote expressing hardship ('really bad deal') related to economic impact, not the health threat.
Reports arrangements wouldn't necessarily cover hospitalization factually.
Reports fear of attention inflaming anti-immigrant fervor, a social concern.
Factual statement about historical pattern.
Provides an example of past events factually.
Reports workers have been told 'very little' factually.
Quote about need for education.
Reports spokespeople did not immediately receive requests factually.
Reports a statement about protective equipment needing to be practical.
Quote about realism of wearing masks.
'most worried' is explicit language indicating concern/alarm.
Quote describing working conditions factually.
Reports where mammals died factually.
Reports test results and cause of death factually.
Reports a patient diagnosis factually.
Reports prior cases came after exposure factually.
Attribution statement.
Reports when/where cows tested positive factually.
Reports a person contracted it and notes it's the 'first known case' factually.
'still very much a bird virus' minimizes the extent of mammalian adaptation/risk.
States an unknown factually.
Reports evidence suggests something is the case factually.
Provides an instance as evidence factually.
Quote stating the 'biggest question' factually.
'the general publicâ€™s risk is low' is explicit reassuring language.
Photo caption describing the image factually.
'is leaving the federal government without the data necessary' frames the situation negatively.
Reports a Senator is paying 'a lot of attention' factually.
Describes what a bill targets factually.
'unsanitary factory farming practices' and 'prioritize profits over public health' are strong negative evaluations.
Reports a department did not immediately respond factually.
'risk... remains low' is explicit reassuring language.
Describes how it spreads factually.
'creates a significant risk' is explicit language indicating elevated risk.
Provides a link for more information factually.
Reports an outbreak location and date factually. 'Highly pathogenic' is technical.
Reports a man hospitalized with the 'first ever human case' factually.
Reports confirmation and diagnosis of the 'rare virus' factually.
Quote stating transmission type factually.
'risk of large-scale transmission is low' is explicit reassuring language.
'mild symptoms' minimizes the severity.
'risk to the general public... remains low' is explicit reassuring language.
Reports confirmation of a case factually.
Reports a previous detection factually.
'risk to most people remains low' is explicit reassuring language.
Reports laboratory tests confirmed a girl 'died' factually.
Reports a man 'had also died' factually.
Reports a girl became the country's 'first bird flu fatality since 2014' factually.
Headline reporting death and 'first known human infection since 2014' factually.
Quote describing virus spread and becoming endemic factually.
Quote reporting human case locations factually.
Describes how people have caught the virus factually.
'she is worried about them' is explicit language indicating concern/alarm from a quoted source.
Defines HPAI and states it can 'sometimes be transferred' factually. 'Highly pathogenic' is technical.
Quote about farmers keeping guard dogs factually.
States human case is same strain that has 'spread rapidly' factually.
Quote about properties being connected factually.
Reports cases were unrelated and where farmers worked factually.
Reports virus is widespread and caused 'ongoing outbreaks' factually.
'mild flu-like upper respiratory symptoms' minimizes the severity.
Headline reporting detection locations factually.
'worried' is explicit language indicating concern/alarm.
Reports trading has 'suffered' and imports blocked factually.
Reports a farm was 'hit by' HPAI factually. 'Highly pathogenic' is technical.
States the predominant strain factually.
'Less reassuring' is explicit language indicating a lack of reassurance/potential concern.
'is a big impact' is an explicit evaluative phrase indicating significant negative consequence.
'tremendous impact' is an explicit intensifier indicating significant negative consequence.
Reports experts say migration patterns are 'likely aiding the spread' factually.
Reports experts said flu 'historically dies out' but this strain 'has been spreading for a longer period' factually.
Reports HPAI detected 'for the first time' factually. 'Highly pathogenic' is technical.
Reports a child tested positive factually.
Reports the variant detected and states it's a 'type of high pathogenicity (HPAI) strain' factually.
Quote describing frequency factually.
Quote stating it's not a relief, a statement about personal feeling regarding a negative fact.
'enormous concern' is explicit language indicating worry/alarm.
'mild respiratory symptoms' minimizes the severity.
Reports a man confirmed as the 'first human case of infection with a rare strain' factually.
States many strains are present and some 'sporadically infect people' factually.
Reports hospitalization and diagnosis dates factually.
Reports a strain of HPAI detected factually. 'Highly pathogenic' is technical.
States the strain is 'potentially deadly' factually.
Reports an outbreak of HPAI factually. 'Highly pathogenic' is technical.
Describes the farm and birds factually.
Reports number of birds that 'had also died' factually.
Reports one of them 'died' factually.
Reports flu affecting wild birds and number of deaths factually.
Lists other wild birds affected factually.
Reports detection in bald eagles in other states factually.
'threat... remains low' is explicit reassuring language.
'taking a toll' is a common idiom for negative impact, not strong amplification.
Reports the outbreak 'has resulted in the culling of more than 23 million poultry' factually.
Describes the result of the outbreak and how birds can 'succumb at a high rate' factually.
Quote reporting number of farms/flocks factually.
'especially troubling' is explicit language indicating concern/alarm.
Reports a past outbreak 'led producers to kill 33 million hens' factually.
Reports smaller outbreaks factually.
Reports cases in states/locations factually.
Describes avian influenza and how it spreads 'easily' factually.
Describes how the virus can spread factually.
Reports the first infection this year factually.
Reports recent cases factually. 'Highly pathogenic' is technical.
Quote about business practice, not framing the threat.
Quote about economic impact, not framing the threat.
Reports number of birds 'killed' factually.
'rising concerns' and 'increasing threats' are explicit language indicating worry/alarm and elevated risk.
'deadly' and 'spread rapidly' are factual descriptions of outcome and speed.
Reports a farm laid off employees after an outbreak forced 'destruction' factually.
'ignited protests' is a vivid verb describing a public reaction, not the threat's impact.
Describes a protest action factually.
Describes the strain's first appearance and movement factually.
Reports the virus 'had taken flight' (metaphor) and was reported in locations factually.
Reports species of wild birds infected factually.
Describes maps showing flu moving 'very clearly' (intensifier on clarity) factually.
Reports an outbreak where cranes were gathered 'killed 8,000 of them' factually.
Reports researchers said opportunities for 'new emerging pathogens' has 'increased' factually.
Points to COVID-19 and lists animals found infected factually.
Quote stating interaction opportunities factually.
Quote stating pathogen behavior factually.
Describes the strain evolving, mutating, and swapping genes factually.
Reports number of human infections factually.
Reports number of human infections and fatalities factually.
'mild symptoms' minimizes the severity.
Reports cases emerged at a farm that was the site of an outbreak factually.
Describes how the disease spreads 'easily' and can prove 'deadly' factually.
'mild flu-like upper respiratory symptoms' minimizes the severity.
Lists factual severe outcomes ('vomiting, seizures, and death') neutrally.
Reports number of human cases factually.
'increasingly skeptical' and 'ground... continues to gain' frame the situation negatively regarding control.
Reports surveys show farmers continued to move cows even after they showed 'signs of disease' factually.
Reports cases were among people involved in 'culling birds' factually.
Reports evidence suggests the virus 'possibly reached' the farm factually.
Quote stating 'does raise the possibility' factually.
Quote stating 'is a hypothesis' factually.
Quote stating 'is a hypothesis' and needs investigation factually.
Quote stating 'is a hypothesis' factually.
'all mild' minimizes the severity.
Factual description of symptoms.
'underscored some of the challenges' frames the situation negatively regarding prevention.
Factual statement about a potential transmission factor.
'much less severe' is explicit language minimizing severity.
Describes size of egg farms factually.
Reports 'sizeable bird flu cases' factually.
Quote stating predictability and preventability factually.
States reassortment has happened factually.
Describes 2009 H1N1 as a 'close cousin' and origin factually.
